Best Swimming Pool Loans

A pool loan can help you cover the cost of installing a swimming pool. Learn how they work and which lenders offer the best.

By J.R. Duren

Written by

J.R. Duren

Freelance writer

J.R. has 17 years of professional writing experience, was a three-time winner at the Florida Press Club Excellence in Journalism contest, and has edited and written about personal finance for the past seven years. His work has appeared at Investopedia, The Balance, LendingTree, and H&R Block.

    View All

    Only 8% of homes in the U.S. have a pool, according to the Pool and Hot Tub Alliance. Why the scarcity? Cost. Pools can be one of the most expensive additions to a home, often costing tens of thousands of dollars. Covering that kind of expense with cash may be impossible for many, but personal loans provide a relatively affordable (and quick) way to finance a swimming pool. Other options include home equity loans, home equity lines of credit, and contractor financing. 

    Compare interest rates on pool loans

    Overview

    LightStream is one of three Credible partner lenders to offer loan amounts up to $100,000, which makes it ideal for financing large expenses. Plus, average rates on LightStream personal loans were the lowest among all Credible partner lenders for borrowers with good, very good, and excellent credit, according to 12 months of Credible personal loans marketplace data. There are no origination fees or other fees, and loans can be used for a wide range of purposes

     

    Funds can be available as soon as the same day you apply, and you could have up to 20 years to repay certain types of loans, including home improvement loans, RV loans, and boat loans. 

     

    Unlike most lenders, LightStream does not let you prequalify on its site — but you can prequalify through Credible. LightStream scored better than average in J.D. Power's 2025 U.S. Consumer Lending Satisfaction Study, beating out online lender SoFi by one position.

    pros

    • Ultra-low interest rates
    • No fees
    • $100,000 loans available
    • Allows co-borrowers
    • Same-day funding possible
    • Repayment terms up to 20 years
    • 6th in consumer lending satisfaction

    cons

    • No loans under $5,000
    • Requires good to excellent credit
    • No changing monthly due dates
    • Limited customer service
    • Can't prequalify on the lender's site

    Overview

    LendingClub makes loans to borrowers across the credit spectrum and stands out for its low rates, based on Credible personal loan data. The lender has some of the lowest average APRs for borrowers with fair credit (FICO 580 - 669), good credit (670 - 739), very good credit (FICO 740 - 799), and excellent credit (FICO 800+), compared to other Credible partner lenders. This plus a low minimum income requirement, nationwide availability, and a mobile app makes LendingClub one of our top picks, especially for debt consolidation loans. 

     

    LendingClub may charge an origination fee between 0% and 8%.

    pros

    • Potentially low rates for fair credit or better
    • Low minimum income requirement
    • Offers joint personal loans
    • Available in all states

    cons

    Overview

    Best Egg is a solid lender for a wide range of borrowers. It offers competitive rates, reasonable loan terms and amounts, and personal loans for fair credit. You'll need a FICO score of at least 600 to qualify, which means borrowers with fair credit are eligible. Plus, Best Egg is one of a handful of Credible partner lenders to offer secured loans, and the only one we know of that offers loans secured by the fixtures in your home. This can be a great way for homeowners to lower their rate, while not putting their actual home up as collateral. 

     

    However, Best Egg loans may have an origination fee, which ranges from 0.99% to 9.99% of the loan amount.

    pros

    • Secured loans available
    • Low minimum income requirement
    • Wide range of loan purposes allowed
    • Funds in 1-3 business days

    cons

    • Origination fees
    • No discounts
    • Not available in DC, IA, VT, or WV

    Loan amount

    Overview

    Upgrade has a suite of features that make it a very attractive lender: competitive interest rates, discounts for direct pay and autopay, as soon as same-day funding, up to seven-year repayment terms, and nationwide availability. Plus, loans are available to fair-credit borrowers and borrowers with low annual incomes. Upgrade even offers secured personal loans, which is not common among lenders.

     

    However, Upgrade does charge an origination fee of 1.85% to 9.99%.

    pros

    • Fair-credit eligible
    • Secured loan options
    • Joint applications accepted
    • Fast funding
    • Small loans available
    • Low income requirement

    cons

    • High APRs for fair credit
    • Origination fees
    • Risk of collateral loss

    Overview

    Splash Financial has a 4.9 / 5-star rating on Trustpilot, with many customers singling out customer service for high marks. It’s worth considering a personal loan through Splash if you have good credit (ideally, a FICO score above Splash's minimum requirement of 680). The platform offers loans from a wide range of lenders, and next-day funding is available. Loans are available up to $100,000 if you apply via Splash’s website.

     

    Rates are competitive, but borrowers with excellent credit may find lower APRs elsewhere. If you need a repayment term longer than six years, you’ll need to look elsewhere as well. 

    pros

    • Excellent customer reviews on Trustpilot
    • Funding as soon as the next business day
    • Large loan amounts available

    cons

    • Possible origination fee up to 7.49% (through Credible)
    • Other lenders may have lower starting APRs
    • No cosigner option

    Loan amount

    $3,000 - $100,000 (up to $50,000 on Credible)

    Fees

    Origination fee

    Discounts

    None

    Eligibility

    Available in all states except VT. OH and NM net disbursed amount must be greater than $5,000. MA must be greater than $6,000

    Min. income

    $25,000

    Phone, email, live chat

    Time to get funds

    Typically 1-3 days

    Overview

    Citi offers no-fee personal loans to borrowers with good credit (a FICO credit score of 720 or higher). No-fee means no origination fees and no late fees, and Citi is one of few lenders that don’t charge either. (Origination fees are deducted from the loan upfront, reducing the amount you receive). 

    The company also offers a generous 0.50 percentage point autopay discount (the lowest rate includes the autopay discount) and makes same day funding available to most current Citi customers. However, Citi requires a relatively high credit score to qualify and caps the amount you can borrow at $30,000, which is less than most of its competitors.

    Citi came in second for overall customer satisfaction in J.D. Power's 2025 Consumer Lending Satisfaction Study.

    pros

    • No origination fees
    • Autopay discount (the lowest rate includes the autopay discount)
    • 2nd in J.D. Power's Consumer Lending Satisfaction Study
    • 100% digital process

    cons

    • Max loan amount is lower than most lenders
    • High credit score required

    Loan amount

    $2,000-$30,000

    Fees

    None

    Discounts

    0.5% APR autopay discount (included in the lowest available rate)

    Eligibility

    Available nationwide

    Min. income

    $30,000

    Customer service

    Email and mobile app

    Soft credit check

    Yes

    Time to get funds

    Same business day for most customers when deposited directly to a Citi® bank account or within 2 business days when deposited directly to a non-Citi® bank account

    Loan uses

    Can be used for almost any purpose, except for using the proceeds for post-secondary expenses or business purposes.

    Overview

    Universal Credit offers loan amounts up to $50,000, repayment terms up to seven years, and discounts for direct pay and autopay. Funds are available as soon as the next business day after loan approval.

     

    Note that rates and fees can be relatively high — you may pay an origination fee from 5.25% to 9.99%, and APRs start at 11.69%. If you get a loan with a high interest rate, consider refinancing your personal loan at a lower rate once you've improved your credit score.

    pros

    • $25,000 annual income requirement
    • Autopay and direct pay discounts available
    • Can fund in one business day

    cons

    • High APRs
    • Potentially high origination fees

    What are pool loans and how do they work?

    Pool loans can be installment loans that disburse the money upfront and require a fixed monthly payment for the entire loan term. In other cases, they could be a revolving line of credit that you use to pay pool cost expenses as they’re due. Common types of installment loans used to finance a pool include personal loans and home equity loans. Revolving credit lines include HELOCs and credit cards. Builder financing may also be an option.

    Tip

    Pool loans typically fall into the category of home improvement loans. The average APR for home improvement loans over the past 12 months was 18.02%, according to Credible personal loans data.

    Pros and cons of personal loans for swimming pools

    One of the biggest benefits of using a personal loan to finance your pool is that there is no home equity requirement — making personal loans an option for more homeowners.

    Pros

    • Fixed interest rate and monthly payments
    • No collateral required
    • Long- and short-term options
    • No home equity requirement
    • Quick funding
    • Can add value to your home
    • Purchasing power
    • Money left for maintenance costs

    Cons

    • Potential origination fees
    • Potential for high APRs
    • Other improvements may have higher ROI
    • Ongoing expenses

    Pros

    • Fixed interest rate and monthly payments: Personal loans for pools have a predictable repayment schedule since your monthly payment and APR don’t change.
    • No collateral required: Pool loans from personal loan lenders are typically unsecured, which means you don’t have to pledge any assets to get the loan. 
    • Long- and short-term options: Lenders that provide pool loans tend to offer multiple repayment terms, which gives you flexibility to opt for a higher monthly payment and lower overall interest costs or a lower monthly payment and higher overall costs across a longer loan term.
    • No home equity requirement: Since personal loans are not secured by your home’s equity, you don’t need a minimum amount of equity to qualify. 
    • Quick funding: Also, since there’s no minimum home equity requirement, your home’s value doesn’t need to be appraised, which can lead to much quicker funding relative to home-equity-based loans.
    • Can add value to your home: The added financing costs of a pool loan may make you hesitant to move forward, but once the pool is installed, you could expect a property value increase between 5% and 8%, according to HGTV. This should offset some of those loan costs.
    • Purchasing power: Pools are expensive, and most homeowners could not pay out of pocket to have one installed. Taking out a pool loan means you can put in the pool of your dreams without having to drain your savings or compromise on the features you want.
    • Money left for maintenance costs: By using a loan to pay for the pool, you’ll leave your savings untouched. That’s important because you’ll need to immediately start thinking about how you’ll pay for related costs, like ongoing pool maintenance, higher water bills, and higher homeowners insurance.

    Cons

    • Potential origination fees: Some lenders charge origination fees that can cost up to or over 10% of your loan amount. 
    • Potential for high APRs: If you don’t have good credit and can qualify for a pool loan, you could pay an APR near 30%.
    • Other improvements may have higher ROI: A pool can increase the value of your home, but you might not get the most bang for your buck. It might make more sense to take on debt for something with a higher return on investment (ROI), such as a new roof, a kitchen remodel, or new windows.
    • Ongoing expenses: Monthly loan repayment for the next several years might make it more challenging to afford pool maintenance, higher water bills, and higher homeowners insurance.

    Good to know

    Lenders that charge origination fees may deduct the fee from your loan amount before you receive your funds. So, if you’re approved for $30,000 and your origination fee is 3% ($900, in this case), you’d receive $29,100.

    How much do swimming pools cost?

    You can expect to pay anywhere from $35,000 to $100,000 for an in-ground pool, says Karen Watts, founder of new-homeowner consulting firm DomiSource. However, that number can vary based on where you live, your pool’s size, and other costs such as custom shapes, decking, and heating.

    For example, a basic pool may cost an average of $55,000 to $75,000 in Texas, says John Uhle, founding partner at Discount Salt Pool. However, a pool built with luxury accommodations such as a heater, lighting, fencing, and decking could easily cost more than $150,000, Watts says, once you factor in the add-ons, permits, and drainage work.

    Expert take: Pool costs don’t stop at installation; budget for monthly and yearly maintenance costs. “Even ‘low-maintenance’ pools will require a commitment of $500 to $1,000 per year for chemicals, cleaning, and service. I always remind homeowners that if you don't budget every year for pool maintenance before you build, you aren't really budgeting.”

    — Karen Watts, DomiSource Founder

    Pool costs with a personal loan

    When you use a pool loan to finance the construction of your new swimming pool, you’ll have to budget for additional costs beyond the materials, permits, and labor. Personal loans for swimming pools come with interest and potentially origination fees.

    Average personal loan rates for home improvement loans through the Credible marketplace typically range between 10% for borrowers with excellent credit to 31% for borrowers with poor credit.

    How to compare pool financing options

    Take your time when shopping for a personal loan to pay for a pool. Not all personal loans are created equal. Prequalify with several lenders and compare all the terms and conditions to choose the right option for you.

    Know your credit score

    Many lenders have minimum credit score requirements. Check your credit score for free using Credible's credit-monitoring tool and see how your score matches up with lenders you're considering.

    Consider APRs

    Personal loan APRs, or annual percentage rates, account for both the interest rate and any upfront lender fees, such as origination fees. APR represents the annualized cost of borrowing. With a purchase as big as a pool, getting a lower APR could save you a significant amount of money on interest.

    Consider term length carefully

    Choosing a shorter pool loan repayment term can save you a lot of money in interest, but it might not be the best move. The shorter the loan term, the higher the monthly payment becomes (since you’re paying the loan back in fewer months).

    Adding a large loan payment to your monthly budget might be difficult, especially as your pool can also involve higher utility bills, maintenance costs, and an increased homeowners insurance premium. Try to find the best balance between a monthly payment you can comfortably afford and total interest costs over the life of the loan.

    Prequalify with a handful of lenders

    To make the best decision, prequalify with multiple lenders online. Review the fine print of each to understand:

    • If each lender offers loan amounts large enough to cover the cost of the pool
    • The APR being offered by each lender
    • The repayment terms available to you
    • The resulting monthly payment with each lender

    Tip

    Use a personal loan marketplace like Credible to prequalify with multiple lenders simultaneously and potentially receive multiple quotes.

    How to get a pool loan

    1. Get a pool estimate. Many contractors and pool companies offer estimates at no cost — get at least a few to compare.
    2. Check your credit score and check your credit report for errors. Dispute any inaccurate or outdated information on your credit report before applying for a loan.
    3. Prequalify with multiple lenders to get an idea of the rates and repayment terms you might be offered. Compare the results. 
    4. Research lenders based on customer satisfaction, contact details, and any features important to you, like whether the lender has a mobile app.
    5. Pick the loan quote and company that best fit your needs and start the application. 
    6. Complete the application and wait for the lender’s decision. 
    7. If you’re approved, you’ll receive a formal loan offer. Read the loan contract carefully to confirm that the rate, terms, monthly payment amount, and all fees are acceptable. 
    8. Sign the loan agreement and related documents to initiate funding.

    Other ways to pay for a swimming pool

    Home equity line of credit (HELOC)

    A HELOC is a popular way to pay for a swimming pool. HELOCs are a line of credit you take out against your home, and the amount you’re approved for is based on the equity you have in your home. 

    HELOC rates tend to be lower than personal loans and credit cards. However, HELOC rates are variable, which means your rate could change over time based on market conditions. As a result, your monthly payment could change monthly as well. You could also lose your home if you can’t keep up with payments.

    HELOCs are divided into draw and repayment periods. During the draw period, you can draw from your line of credit and make interest-only payments on what you pull out. During the repayment period, you can’t draw from your HELOC and your monthly payments include principal and interest.

    Home equity loan

    Home equity loans are very similar to personal loans in that you make fixed monthly payments based on a fixed interest rate, and you receive the money upfront. The big difference is that, like with a HELOC, you use your home as collateral, which means you could lose it if you default on payments. 

    Good to know

    The average homeowner has $212,000 in tappable home equity — meaning, the amount they can access while maintaining 20% equity. Keeping at least 20% of equity in the home is often required to get a HELOC or home equity loan.

    Contractor financing

    The contractor you choose to build your pool may offer financing. If that’s an option, be sure to review the terms of the lender’s financing and prequalify (if you can) to get a sense of what your financing rate and terms would be. Some contractors may offer 0% promotions that allow you to make payments without interest for a certain number of months.

    Warning

    With “deferred interest” financing, you’ll be charged the full amount of interest that was deferred if you don’t pay off your loan by the end of the promotional period.

    Methodology 

    Credible evaluated 32 lenders across 1,216 data points to find the best pool loans among personal loan lenders. We feature lenders that offer loans for home improvement and one or more of the following factors: high loan amounts, low rates, and financing options for fair credit.

    Lender star ratings were established based on the following weighted categories:

    • Rates and fees: 18.75%
    • Eligibility and options for bad and no credit: 17.5%
    • Availability: 12.5%
    • Loan amounts and terms: 10%
    • Customer satisfaction: 10%
    • Customer service: 10%
    • Efficiency and fund delivery: 10%
    • Discounts: 7.5%
    • Credible proprietary data: 3.75%

    Credible’s team of experts gathered information from each lender’s website and from our partners directly. We also considered each of our partner lenders’ statistics over a 12-month period — including average funding times, average credit scores for approved applicants, and average rates. Each data point is verified by a senior editor to make sure it’s accurate at the time of publication. 

    Learn more about how Credible rates lenders by exploring our personal loans lender rating methodology.

    Credible is a personal loans marketplace that partners directly with lenders to offer loans for a wide range of credit profiles and loan purposes. Because of these relationships, we have access to the most current interest rates that real borrowers are being approved for, along with average rates by credit score and loan purpose, approval rates overall and by lender, and more. The data we use is primary source data, updated weekly, and does not include any personally identifiable information about borrowers.

    Why trust Credible

    The Credible editorial team is independent and unbiased — we base ratings on a data-driven process and apply rating algorithms uniformly to ensure fair comparisons between lenders. We never get paid to rank products or lending partners.

    Our expert editorial staff analyzed 1,216 personal loan data points across 32 lenders, assessing rates, fees, customer experience, and more to simplify your personal loan comparison. For a deeper dive into our process, see our detailed methodology.

    Credible has a 4.8 out of 5 star rating with Trustpilot, based on over 8,000 reviews. 

    FAQ

    What is the minimum credit score required to qualify for a pool loan?

    Open

    You may be able to qualify for a pool loan with a score in the upper 500s or low to mid 600s, but your rate will be high and you may need to offer collateral or get a cosigner. Minimum credit score requirements vary by lender, and some have no minimum. 

    What is the average term for a swimming pool loan?

    Open

    Repayment terms for swimming pool loans can range from two years to more than 20 years. The repayment terms available to you depend on the type of pool financing you choose (such as a home equity loan or a personal loan), as well as the specific lender you go with. The cost of your project could also impact the length of the repayment period you qualify for.

    How long does it take to get approved for a pool loan?

    Open

    How quickly you can get approved for a pool loan depends on the lender, as well as whether additional materials or information are needed beyond the application. Some lenders offer approval as soon as the same day you apply.

    Can you refinance a swimming pool loan?

    Open

    Yes, you can typically refinance a swimming pool loan. Whether you take out a personal loan, a home equity loan, or use contractor financing, you can often refinance if rates decrease with either the same lender (in some cases) or a different lender.

    Disclosure: Some lending partners that participate in Credible’s comparison marketplace offer loans to borrowers with scores as low as 550. Borrowers with low scores will have fewer lending options than borrowers with higher credit scores.
